            <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
             {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}a&amp;={\frac {r_{a}+r_{p}}{2}}\\b&amp;={\sqrt {r_{a}\cdot r_{p}}}\\l&amp;={\frac {2}{{\frac {1}{r_{a}}}+{\frac {1}{r_{p}}}}}={\frac {2r_{a}r_{p}}{r_{a}+r_{p}}}\end{aligned}}}
            </annotation>
           </semantics>
          </math>
         </span>
         <img alt="{\begin{aligned}a&amp;={\frac {r_{a}+r_{p}}{2}}\\b&amp;={\sqrt {r_{a}\cdot r_{p}}}\\l&amp;={\frac {2}{{\frac {1}{r_{a}}}+{\frac {1}{r_{p}}}}}={\frac {2r_{a}r_{p}}{r_{a}+r_{p}}}\end{aligned}}" aria-hidden="true" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bce153ae6097d597df4f97215de36249f3b00e89" style="vertical-align: -7.671ex; width:24.651ex; height:16.509ex;"/>
        </span>
        .
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Harmonic_oscillators">
        Harmonic oscillators
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Harmonic oscillators">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The general solution for a
       <a href="/wiki/Harmonic_oscillator" title="Harmonic oscillator">
        harmonic oscillator
       </a>
       in two or more
       <a href="/wiki/Dimension" title="Dimension">
        dimensions
       </a>
       is also an ellipse. Such is the case, for instance, of a long pendulum that is free to move in two dimensions; of a mass attached to a fixed point by a perfectly elastic
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spring_(mechanics)" title="Spring (mechanics)">
        spring
       </a>
       ; or of any object that moves under influence of an attractive force that is directly proportional to its distance from a fixed attractor. Unlike Keplerian orbits, however, these "harmonic orbits" have the center of attraction at the geometric center of the ellipse, and have fairly simple equations of motion.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Phase_visualization">
        Phase visualization
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Phase visualization">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In
       <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">
        electronics
       </a>
       , the relative phase of two sinusoidal signals can be compared by feeding them to the vertical and horizontal inputs of an
       <a href="/wiki/Oscilloscope" title="Oscilloscope">
        oscilloscope
       </a>
       . If the display is an ellipse, rather than a straight line, the two signals are out of phase.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Elliptical_gears">
        Elliptical gears
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Elliptical gears">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Two
       <a href="/wiki/Non-circular_gear" title="Non-circular gear">
        non-circular gears
       </a>
       with the same elliptical outline, each pivoting around one focus and positioned at the proper angle, turn smoothly while maintaining contact at all times. Alternatively, they can be connected by a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Link_chain" title="Link chain">
        link chain
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Toothed_belt" title="Toothed belt">
        timing belt
       </a>
       , or in the case of a bicycle the main
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chainwheel#ovoid_chainwheels" title="Chainwheel">
        chainring
       </a>
       may be elliptical, or an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ovoid" title="Ovoid">
        ovoid
       </a>
       similar to an ellipse in form. Such elliptical gears may be used in mechanical equipment to produce variable
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Angular_speed" title="Angular speed">
        angular speed
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Torque" title="Torque">
        torque
       </a>
       from a constant rotation of the driving axle, or in the case of a bicycle to allow a varying crank rotation speed with inversely varying
       <a href="/wiki/Mechanical_advantage" title="Mechanical advantage">
        mechanical advantage
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Elliptical bicycle gears make it easier for the chain to slide off the cog when changing gears.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       An example gear application would be a device that winds thread onto a conical
       <a href="/wiki/Bobbin" title="Bobbin">
        bobbin
       </a>
       on a
       <a href="/wiki/Spinning_(textiles)" title="Spinning (textiles)">
        spinning
       </a>
       machine. The bobbin would need to wind faster when the thread is near the apex than when it is near the base.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Optics">
        Optics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Optics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <ul>
       <li>
        In a material that is optically
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anisotropic" title="Anisotropic">
         anisotropic
        </a>
        (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birefringent" title="Birefringent">
         birefringent
        </a>
        ), the
        <a href="/wiki/Refractive_index" title="Refractive index">
         refractive index
        </a>
        depends on the direction of the light. The dependency can be described by an
        <a href="/wiki/Index_ellipsoid" title="Index ellipsoid">
         index ellipsoid
        </a>
        . (If the material is optically
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isotropic" title="Isotropic">
         isotropic
        </a>
        , this ellipsoid is a sphere.)
       </li>
       <li>
        In lamp-
        <a href="/wiki/Laser_pumping" title="Laser pumping">
         pumped
        </a>
        solid-state lasers, elliptical cylinder-shaped reflectors have been used to direct light from the pump lamp (coaxial with one ellipse focal axis) to the active medium rod (coaxial with the second focal axis).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
         <a href="#cite_note-18">
          [18]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        In laser-plasma produced
        <a href="/wiki/Extreme_ultraviolet" title="Extreme ultraviolet">
         EUV
        </a>
        light sources used in microchip
        <a href="/wiki/Extreme_ultraviolet_lithography" title="Extreme ultraviolet lithography">
         lithography
        </a>
        , EUV light is generated by plasma positioned in the primary focus of an ellipsoid mirror and is collected in the secondary focus at the input of the lithography machine.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
         <a href="#cite_note-19">
          [19]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Statistics_and_finance">
        Statistics and finance
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Statistics and finance">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In
       <a href="/wiki/Statistics" title="Statistics">
        statistics
       </a>
       , a bivariate
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Random_vector" title="Random vector">
        random vector
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        X
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        Y
       </i>
       ) is
       <a href="/wiki/Elliptical_distribution" title="Elliptical distribution">
        jointly elliptically distributed
       </a>
       if its iso-density contours—loci of equal values of the density function—are ellipses. The concept extends to an arbitrary number of elements of the random vector, in which case in general the iso-density contours are
       <a href="/wiki/Ellipsoid" title="Ellipsoid">
        ellipsoids
       </a>
       . A special case is the
       <a href="/wiki/Multivariate_normal_distribution" title="Multivariate normal distribution">
        multivariate normal distribution
       </a>
       . The elliptical distributions are important in
       <a href="/wiki/Finance" title="Finance">
        finance
       </a>
       because if rates of return on assets are jointly elliptically distributed then all portfolios can be characterized completely by their mean and variance—that is, any two portfolios with identical mean and variance of portfolio return have identical distributions of portfolio return.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Computer_graphics">
        Computer graphics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Computer graphics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Drawing an ellipse as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Graphics_primitive" title="Graphics primitive">
        graphics primitive
       </a>
       is common in standard display libraries, such as the MacIntosh
       <a href="/wiki/QuickDraw" title="QuickDraw">
        QuickDraw
       </a>
       API, and
       <a href="/wiki/Direct2D" title="Direct2D">
        Direct2D
       </a>
       on Windows.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jack_Bresenham" title="Jack Bresenham">
        Jack Bresenham
       </a>
       at IBM is most famous for the invention of 2D drawing primitives, including line and circle drawing, using only fast integer operations such as addition and branch on carry bit. M. L. V. Pitteway extended Bresenham's algorithm for lines to conics in 1967.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Another efficient generalization to draw ellipses was invented in 1984 by Jerry Van Aken.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1970 Danny Cohen presented at the "Computer Graphics 1970" conference in England a linear algorithm for drawing ellipses and circles. In 1971, L. B. Smith published similar algorithms for all conic sections and proved them to have good properties.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These algorithms need only a few multiplications and additions to calculate each vector.
      </p>
      <p>
       It is beneficial to use a parametric formulation in computer graphics because the density of points is greatest where there is the most curvature. Thus, the change in slope between each successive point is small, reducing the apparent "jaggedness" of the approximation.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Drawing with Bézier paths
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Composite_B%C3%A9zier_curve" title="Composite Bézier curve">
        Composite Bézier curves
       </a>
       may also be used to draw an ellipse to sufficient accuracy, since any ellipse may be construed as an
       <a href="/wiki/Affine_transformation" title="Affine transformation">
        affine transformation
       </a>
       of a circle. The spline methods used to draw a circle may be used to draw an ellipse, since the constituent
       <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve" title="Bézier curve">
        Bézier curves
       </a>
       behave appropriately under such transformations.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Optimization_theory">
        Optimization theory
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Optimization theory">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       It is sometimes useful to find the minimum bounding ellipse on a set of points. The
       <a href="/wiki/Ellipsoid_method" title="Ellipsoid method">
        ellipsoid method
       </a>
       is quite useful for attacking this problem.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
        See also
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellipse&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: See also">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Apollonius_of_Perga" title="Apollonius of Perga">
          Apollonius of Perga
         </a>
         , the classical authority
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Cartesian_oval" title="Cartesian oval">
          Cartesian oval
         </a>
         , a generalization of the ellipse
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Circumconic_and_inconic" title="Circumconic and inconic">
          Circumconic and inconic
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Conic_section" title="Conic section">
          Conic section
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ellipse_fitting" title="Ellipse fitting">
          Ellipse fitting
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Ellipsoid" title="Ellipsoid">
          Ellipsoid
         </a>
         , a higher dimensional analog of an ellipse
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Elliptic_coordinates" title="Elliptic coordinates">
          Elliptic coordinates
         </a>
         , an orthogonal coordinate system based on families of ellipses and
         <a href="/wiki/Hyperbola" title="Hyperbola">
          hyperbolae
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Elliptic_partial_differential_equation" title="Elliptic partial differential equation">
          Elliptic partial differential equation
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Elliptical_distribution" title="Elliptical distribution">
          Elliptical distribution
         </a>
         , in statistics
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Geodesics_on_an_ellipsoid" title="Geodesics on an ellipsoid">
          Geodesics on an ellipsoid
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Great_ellipse" title="Great ellipse">
          Great ellipse
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Hyperbola" title="Hyperbola">
          Hyperbola
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Kepler%27s_laws_of_planetary_motion" title="Kepler's laws of planetary motion">
          Kepler's laws of planetary motion
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Matrix_representation_of_conic_sections" title="Matrix representation of conic sections">
          Matrix representation of conic sections
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/N-ellipse" title="N-ellipse">
          <i>
           n
          </i>
          -ellipse
         </a>
         , a generalization of the ellipse for
         <i>
          n
         </i>
         foci
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Oval" title="Oval">
          Oval
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Parabola" title="Parabola">
          Parabola
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Rytz%27s_construction" title="Rytz's construction">
          Rytz’s construction
         </a>
         , a method for finding the ellipse axes from
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tangent_parallelogram" title="Tangent parallelogram">
          conjugate diameters
         </a>
         or a
         <a href="/wiki/Parallelogram" title="Parallelogram">
          parallelogram
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Spheroid" title="Spheroid">
          Spheroid
         </a>
         , the ellipsoid obtained by rotating an ellipse about its major or minor axis
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Steiner_circumellipse" title="Steiner circumellipse">
          Steiner circumellipse
         </a>
         , the unique ellipse circumscribing a triangle and sharing its centroid
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Steiner_inellipse" title="Steiner inellipse">
          Steiner inellipse
         </a>
         , the unique ellipse inscribed in a triangle with tangencies at the sides' midpoints
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Superellipse" title="Superellipse">
          Superellipse
         </a>
         , a generalization of an ellipse that can look more rectangular or more "pointy"
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/True_anomaly" title="True anomaly">
          True
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Eccentric_anomaly" title="Eccentric anomaly">
          eccentric
         </a>
         , and
         <a href="/wiki/Mean_anomaly" title="Mean anomaly">
          mean anomaly
         </a>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>

         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>

           </a>

           </i>

           </b>

           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1017%2Fs0080456800030817" rel="nofollow">
            10.1017/s0080456800030817
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Transactions+of+the+Royal+Society+of+Edinburgh&amp;rft.atitle=A+new+series+for+the+rectification+of+the+ellipsis&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.pages=177-190&amp;rft.date=1798&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2Fs0080456800030817&amp;rft.aulast=Ivory&amp;rft.aufirst=J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFaUaqZZYYPAC%26pg%3DPA177&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEllipse">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-10">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-10">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal" id="CITEREFBessel1825">
           <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Bessel" title="Friedrich Bessel">
            Bessel, F. W.
           </a>
           (2010). "The calculation of longitude and latitude from geodesic measurements (1825)".
           <i>
            Astron. Nachr

           Smith, L.B. (1971).
           <a class="external text" href="http://comjnl.oxfordjournals.org/content/14/1/81.short" rel="nofollow">
            "Drawing ellipses, hyperbolae or parabolae with a fixed number of points"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            The Computer Journal
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            14
           </b>
           (1): 81–86.
           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1093%2Fcomjnl%2F14.1.81" rel="nofollow">
            10.1093/comjnl/14.1.81
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Computer+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Drawing+ellipses%2C+hyperbolae+or+parabolae+with+a+fixed+number+of+points&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=81-86&amp;rft.date=1971&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1093%2Fcomjnl%2F14.1.81&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+L.B.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fcomjnl.oxfordjournals.org%2Fcontent%2F14%2F1%2F81.short&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEllipse">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>
